awd_titl_txt: SG: Spatial and environmental barriers to gene flow driving cyanobacterial biogeography in a river network.
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans rely on bacteria for nutrient recycling and many other essential functions. Scientists continue to discover increasing bacterial diversity as molecular methods improve. However, scientists do not understand how this genetic diversity relates to the evolution of new and ecologically important species. Better understanding of the processes that create bacterial diversity is needed, particularly in light of their useful functions in ecosystems. This research will study a group of bacteria, the cyanobacteria, that use light to sequester carbon and produce oxygen. New cyanobacterial species may form when barriers, such as distance or environmental conditions, isolate them and reduce the exchange of genes across populations. That exchange is called "gene flow". No one knows if it is distance, or the differences in environment, that prevent gene flow in these important organisms. This project will collect mats of cyanobacteria throughout the Eel River of Northwestern California, and the researchers will investigate the genetic similarity of those mats across different locations. Cyanobacteria will be sampled from distant locations with similar environments and adjacent locations with different environments. The data will be used to determine what is most important in creating cyanobacterial diversity. A local media organization will collaborate on the project. They will help a group of high school students to create a short science documentary film. Students will film the research done in the field and in the lab to gain knowledge about science communication. Their film and the project findings will be used by local schools. 

This research will investigate genomic patterns and ecological processes that suggest how spatial and environmental barriers to gene flow differentiate cyanobacterial populations, generating nascent genetic diversity. These barriers are predicted to produce different patterns of nucleotide differentiation at neutral and adaptive loci. Therefore, more understanding of the processes driving biogeographical patterns of microbes can be achieved with analyses of closely related co-existing wild bacterial populations collected over variety of spatial scales. Benthic cyanobacterial mats (Phormidium spp.) and environmental variables will be sampled in the river network in a nested design spanning pairwise distances of centimeters to hundreds of kilometers across diverse habitats, from warm sunny downstream habitats to cool shaded tributaries. Using whole genome metagenomic analyses, patterns of nucleotide variation at loci throughout the genome will be compared and will be used to understand 1) the strength of sub-species population diversity in a widespread cyanobacterial genus, 2) the spatial scales of cyanobacterial population diversity, and 3) the contributions of spatial and environmental barriers to gene flow in driving the observed biogeographical patterns.

por.por_cntn:
We proposed to use Microcoleus (Cyanobacteria) genomes, recovered through metagenomic analyses, to study patterns of nucleotide differentiation, driven by genetic isolation and exchange, and gene flow barriers controlling microbial diversification at the watershed scale. River networks, with juxtaposed spatial and environmental structure, are well suited to test hypotheses of environmental and spatial isolation. Understanding the thresholds and strengths of spatial and environmental gene flow barriers in natural microbial populations will identify where and under what conditions these different barriers generate the biogeographical patterns we observe across landscapes and riverscapes.

To investigate the biogeographical patterns in a watershed (Eel River watershed, Mendocino and Humboldt counties, California, USA), we collected Microcoleus samples in a nested design to sample genetic differentiation at five natural scales spanning millimeters to kilometers: 1) within a mat (mm-cm), 2) between mats within a riffle (m), 3) among tributary tips (km), 4) on tributaries and along adjacent mainstems above and below confluence nodes (m), and 5) between sub-watersheds (10s-100s of km). Sampling across environmental and spatial gradients will enable us to investigate hypotheses about microbial population structure and biogeography. We also performed a reciprocal transplant field experiment, moving Microcoleus patches between sunny, warm mainstem location and a cooler, shadier tributary, and to study local the effects of local adaptation on growth rates.

We predict that if environmental selection of adaptive loci is a dominant process driving genetic differentiation of Microcoleus, strong environmental variation will select for different genes increasing genetic divergence at adaptive loci and creating differentiation islands, even within highly connected reaches of a river network. As these loci diverge, genetic recombination decreases as nucleotide sequences become less similar in different environments, leading to divergence at neutral loci and creating stable genotypic clusters. If, on the other hand, spatial barriers like distance have strong effects, then neutral genetic differentiation among cyanobacterial samples will increase, due to genetic drift, and without the stabilizing effect of natural selection acting adaptive sites. Both environmental and spatial barriers, of course, could contribute to genome differentiation of Microcoleus over various spatial and temporal scales in ways that we hope our surveys and transplant experiments will begin to clarify.

From our data we planned to test three hypotheses:

H1: Microcoleus mats within the watershed are not a homogenous panmictic population, but have sub- populations structured by environmental conditions and spatial distances.

H2: Spatial and environmental barriers to gene flow operate over different nested scales within the heterogeneous, but iterated, river environment to drive sub-population biogeography.

H3: Downstream dispersal will bring cells or colonies from a variety of upstream sources into common downstream reaches, homogenizing genotypes, reducing genetic differentiation in larger catchments.

Our results, published in Bouma-Gregson et al. (2022, Molecular Ecology), did not find evidence to support Hypothesis 1. In contrast, we found that the population of Microcoleus strains within the Eel River watershed was well mixed and well-defined sub-populations were not present. Dispersal within the watershed appears to be frequent and far-reaching, therefore few spatial barriers to gene flow occur at the watershed scale, therefore we conclude that environmental selection plays a stronger role in determining where Microcoleus proliferate within the watershed (Hypothesis 2). Lastly, we did not find evidence of more homogeneous genotypes within larger watersheds, and were surprised to find high genetic diversity within small, and seemingly isolated, creeks and tributaries (Hypothesis 3).

Processes driving bacterial evolution over time are still being uncovered. While basic evolutionary mechanisms are understood, the magnitude and impact of these mechanisms across time and space and for different bacterial taxa remain poorly understood. Much evolutionary and biogeographical work has been performed on single celled cyanobacteria from hot springs and from the ocean. Our studies of filamentous freshwater taxa offer important comparisons to see how generalizable the ocean and hot springs results are to other taxa within the cyanobacterial clade. 

Our results show that cyanobacteria in the genus Microcoleus in Northern California form a metapopulation with unstable local sub-populations, but high dispersal and connectivity among sub-populations. We have begun to identify spatial scales of genetic differentiation among closely related cyanobacterial strains and have advanced our understanding of how cyanobacterial strains, not species, are distributed across a watershed. This work informs our understanding of how fine-scale genetic differences affect ecological interactions and ecosystem functions.

Additionally, this project helped initiate a collaboration among researchers in Dr. Banfield's lab, which led to the creation of a new software program (inStrain; https://instrain.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for bacterial strains analysis. The program improves on other methods for detecting variation in genomic sequences. Other software programs do not effectively use the information provided by paired end sequencing reads, and inStrain better leverages this information to improve analysis of sequence variations. We also worked with a local education non-profit, Young Media Makers, to make a series of short videos about algae in the Eel River (https://vimeo.com/eelriveralgae).
